Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Charged Buckybowls: Self-Assembly and Metal Ion Intercalation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the MSN Chemistry Program supports work of Professor Marina A. Petrukhina at the University at Albany, SUNY, to explore multiple electron uptakes by bowl-shaped polyaromatic hydrocarbons (also known as buckybowls or fullerene fragments). In this program, buckybowls mapping onto the surfaces of fullerenes and representing the end-caps of nanotubes are utilized as effective models for a diverse range of carbon-rich nanosize materials, thus providing an excellent opportunity to study the redox properties of curved and strained pi-systems at the molecular level. Specifically, the effects of charging pi-bowls with multiple electrons on their molecular geometry, metal binding abilities and self-assembly will be broadly investigated. As a result, this program should improve our understanding of the redox behavior and electron transport of carbonaceous nanostructured materials. It should assist in elucidation of alkali metal ion intercalation in between non-planar pi-carbon surfaces, which is important for search and design of prospective carbon-based anode materials for Li-ion batteries.

This fundamental program should overall advance the materials chemistry applications of curved carbon-rich polyarenes, including buckybowls, fullerenes, and nanotubes in several emerging fields ranging from electronics to energy storage. This program will also make its major impact on the enhancement of the educational and research experiences of graduate and undergraduate students at the University at Albany by engaging them into a modern cross-disciplinary research program, and thus improving their future career prospects in the highly competitive global marketplace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits. With the funds provided by the National Science Foundation CHE-1212441 award, a broad fundamental program of investigation of controlled functionalization and stepwise chemical reduction processes of a new class of bowl-shaped polycyclic hydrocarbons has been established at the Department of Chemistry, University at Albany, NY. This program explored the structural consequences of adding selected functional groups as well multiple electrons to carbon π-bowls followed by investigations of metal binding and self-assembly trends of charged and curved carbanions. During the award period, we developed efficient synthetic protocols that allowed the isolation of carbon bowls with modulated properties and variable reduction states and completed full characterization of the resulting products. Overall, this program has advanced our fundamental understanding of structures and properties of carbon-rich nanostructured materials and opened the door for design of new derivatives with tailored structures and properties.

The results were described in one book chapter and 31 research manuscripts published since 2012 in a variety of peer-reviewed scientific journals. Among those are four Angew. Chem., three JACS, Adv. Mater., two Chem. Sci., Carbon, Chem. Commun., four Chem. Eur. J., and five Organometallics manuscripts, several of which were selected as Very Important Papers and highlighted in C&EN, Nature Chem., RCS Chem. World, JACS Spotlight and also featured on multiple journal covers. We also contributed two comprehensive reviews (Adv. Organomet. Chem. and Coord. Chem. Rev.) and a mini-review (Chem. Eur. J.). The results were reported by the PI and graduate students at multiple National and Regional ACS meetings, as well as at several international conferences. Over the reported period, the PI presented 15 seminars at different universities in the US and Europe and delivered several talks in Albany.

Broader Impacts. In the course of the above research activities, an educational program was created for training young chemists who became proficient in organic and inorganic synthesis, crystal growth, X-ray diffraction and variable spectroscopic techniques. The program participants also developed good understanding of current challenges and applications of carbonaceous and carbon-rich nanomaterials. This project was used to train six graduate (one international exchange) students, two postdoctoral associates and two staff members (X-ray crystallographers). All students and postdocs participating in this NSF-supported program co-authored multiple research manuscripts. Three Ph.D. students successfully defended their research proposals and one received a PhD degree that was recognized by the very competitive University at Albany Distinguished Doctoral Dissertation Award. Several graduate students received international and national awards that include the prestigious international Ludo Frevel Crystallographic Scholarship from the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) won in 2012 and 2013; a DAAD “RICE Professional” Scholarship to support the summer 2014 industrial internship at Siemens in Germany; the International Union of Crystallography 2014 Student Travel Award to deliver an oral lecture at the IUCr Congress in Montreal, Canada; the Eli Lilly ACS Woman Chemists Committee Travel Award to present an oral talk at the National ACS meeting in 2015. Two undergraduate students from the University at Albany Honors College participated in this program and publicly defended their B.S. Honors dissertations in 2013 and 2015 based on the results obtained in the course of their undergraduate research. Both students co-authored manuscripts and received special recognitions, such as the 1st Shelton Banks Prize for Excellence in Research in Chemistry in 2013 for undergraduate research achievements and the Chemistry Faculty Award in 2015 for demonstrating high scholastic standing and potential for advancement in the chemical profession. These students are now enrolled into graduate programs in Chemistry at prestigious universities in US and Canada.

Additionally, stemming from this fundamental program the university-industry cooperation with Siemens AG Technology Research and Technology Center (Germany) has been established. Two graduate students from both sides participated in three months exchange research visits. As a result, two UAlbany-Siemens patent applications have been filed, and one joint manuscript was published in Adv. Mater. (highlighted in C&EN). Using the results obtained in this program, the PI has also participated in two successful NSF-MRI grant applications (as a co-PI) that were awarded and allowed the acquisition of two major instruments, Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer (2013-2016) and Ambient Ionization Mass Spectrometer (2014-2017). These new additions have greatly improved the research infrastructure at the Department of Chemistry, University at Albany, NY.
